[10.0s - 21.6s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth community podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today we're visiting with Lin Boutsa from the Gretionum in Switzerland, Highland.

[22.3s - 23.2s]: Hi everybody.

[23.2s - 27.9s]: It's great to be with you today. Thanks for having me.

[28.8s - 38.1s]: Absolutely. So Lin is scientific collaborator and project management at the section for agriculture at the Gretionum.

[38.8s - 44.2s]: And the Gretionum is the global center for Rudolph Steiner's work and for the biodynamic movement.

[44.2s - 56.6s]: She has extensive experience in research and science related to organic agriculture and climate stabilization strategies.

[57.2s - 64.0s]: She did her bachelor of science at Brandon Bergshire Technischer University to co-edbus in Germany.

[64.0s - 71.0s]: And also did her masters in science at the Ebersvalda University for sustainable development.

[71.5s - 90.3s]: She has published numerous articles and research papers on these topics, including one called organic farming, climate change mitigation and beyond, reducing the environmental impacts of the European Union agriculture.

[91.2s - 102.4s]: And so a particular import and interest is that the Gretionum is hosting its annual biodynamic conference in just a few weeks time.

[102.6s - 110.6s]: And we're going to share some really exciting ways that people from all over can engage and get involved with this wonderful event.

[110.6s - 123.4s]: And I want to mention to that Lin before working at the Gretionum was doing work at the research institute of organic agriculture as scientific coordinator for Solmack.

[123.5s - 137.6s]: And that's the strategies for organic and low input farming to mitigate and adapt to climate change where she was doing research particularly focused on agricultural projects in Germany, Italy and Sweden.

[138.2s - 157.2s]: So Lin, it's absolutely wonderful to have this opportunity to visit with you. And I'm so excited to have you share with us the work you all are doing at the Gretionum and that you're helping lead in the global biodynamic movement. So welcome.

[158.0s - 161.2s]: Thank you very much. I'm happy to share.

[162.0s - 176.0s]: Excellent. I'd like to I'd like to kick it right off by asking you to tell us what is the upcoming, you know, conference all about and why is it a particular importance right now in these times.

[176.8s - 176.9s]: Yeah.

[176.9s - 185.1s]: So the upcoming conference will be a climate conference and the topic will be briefing in the climate crisis.

[186.2s - 193.3s]: And we're doing this in collaboration with the youth section at the Gretionum. So we really want to involve the youth in it.

[193.3s - 206.0s]: And the idea is to really show that climate change and finding solutions for climate change is not a one dimensional problem, but that we have to tackle it from various dimension.

[206.9s - 220.4s]: And in biodynamics, this is really a core issue because you look at agriculture in a way where you include the social and the environment perspective and the economic perspective.

[220.4s - 227.8s]: But you broaden this perspective also by the spiritual dimension and to really include the spirituality as well.

[228.3s - 244.3s]: And that's why we will look at these different core themes and show the how they are interconnected and yeah, by this we would like to provide holistic solutions for this problem we are facing.

[244.3s - 260.3s]: And actually the theme was initiated before Corona, but I think briefing in the climate crisis becomes quite a double sided dimension at the moment as we are in this pandemic.

[261.3s - 282.0s]: And yeah, the idea is to be able to breathe again and to really come out of the conference and have solutions for farmers, but also for us as youth young people so that we know how we can live in this world and continue to live in this world.

[284.0s - 296.4s]: It's so wonderful. I am so excited and I'm really looking forward to participating and I think the why on earth community is going to help host one of the regional events.

[296.4s - 303.1s]: It will be pretty small because of COVID obviously, but there are so many different ways people can engage.

[303.1s - 308.5s]: Of course, a lot of this will be done online and through video and so on.

[309.5s - 325.5s]: So I just I want to be really emphatic in inviting any of our audience who would like to dive deeper and learn more and also build more community with folks like you, Lin and your colleagues who are really helping to provide these holistic solutions.

[325.5s - 337.7s]: And I think that's such an important key in all of this. And to me, it's encouraging. We're seeing more and more integration between economics and environmental and social and even the spiritual dimensions.

[338.7s - 349.2s]: And it's interesting because in a lot of the scientific work and realm over the last several decades, it's there's been a lot of exclusion of the spiritual.

[365.4s - 379.8s]: Yeah, I mean, I think not everybody is sharing the same beliefs, but one thing that that is good is that many scientists work at the same time at this topic as well.

[379.8s - 396.7s]: And by this scientific proof is given. And I mean, recently just one of the studies came out that, for example, organic and bio dynamic farming is producing much more carbon in the soil because of the root grows of the plants.

[396.7s - 404.7s]: And these numbers help us on the one hand to to argue in this way of farming and say, okay, it's not just spirituality.

[405.6s - 416.5s]: And even if you don't believe in the spiritual way for yourself, the numbers are scientifically proven to help tackle an important issue that we face globally.

[417.5s - 425.2s]: And I think then everybody can decide if he or she wants to join the spirit of the dimension or not.

[425.5s - 429.8s]: And I think that's a freedom of choice, but yeah.

[430.5s - 445.4s]: Absolutely. And it's been my experience helping to host and offer bio dynamic stir ceremonies with soil activating preparations for communities all around the country.

[445.4s - 467.1s]: That bio dynamics provides a really unique and potent venue and context for people with a variety of spiritual and religious backgrounds to come together in the very grounded connected practices working with the water and the preparations and the soil and the plants and the animals.

[467.1s - 478.3s]: And so it seems to me to provide a unique nexus and I haven't found anything else that can do that in quite such a powerful way.

[479.4s - 490.3s]: Yeah. And I mean, you can really feel it as well. If you visit the bio dynamic farm, it's it's a different atmosphere and it's you don't need to be a very spiritual person to experience, but.

[490.3s - 501.0s]: But when you come at the farm, you feel maybe at home or if you eat the food of a bio dynamic farm, it has a different taste and it warms you in a different way.

[501.3s - 517.2s]: So everybody can experience this experience in a personal way and that's the beauty about bio dynamic farming that gives an entry point for each person where they're standing in life.

[518.5s - 546.2s]: Yeah, it's so beautiful. I have friends farming at sustainable settings in carbon deal Colorado up in the mountains, which is near Aspen, which of course has some very high end fine dining and some of the most celebrated chefs in the world really and they prefer sourcing produce and other food products from the bio dynamic farm because of the taste profile.

[546.2s - 551.2s]: It's very interesting that you know they're noticing a real difference.

[551.6s - 564.1s]: Yeah, and sometimes you even see it in the vegetables, for example, you can also see it by by just looking at the vegetables, how the structures are different in in bio dynamics, who bio dynamic produced food.

[644.3s - 657.6s]: Yeah, so you got the idea of pretty right from the living farms project of the ideas to really show what bio dynamic places offer in this global challenges that we face.

[657.9s - 671.7s]: And of course, this global challenges does not just include climate change, but also biodiversity loss and reduced soil fertility, nutrient run of water beautification.

[671.7s - 680.8s]: So all of this problems that say with the convention agriculture system evolves and spread even further.

[682.2s - 696.2s]: And yeah, we realized that biodynamic farming office a lot of possibilities to reduce these challenges and to really overcome these challenges.

[696.2s - 710.5s]: And when I worked for the research Institute of Organic Agriculture in Switzerland as well, one of the main questions I asked myself and the research was we know so much at the moment.

[710.5s - 725.9s]: And we know basically which farming techniques are sustainable and we know how good food system would look like, but what is really lacking is this adaptation of the farmers.

[725.9s - 739.2s]: So what are the struggles that farmers face to take over these measurements and to say I would like to change to a sustainable agriculture system.

[740.1s - 753.5s]: And I don't know how this in the US actually, but for Europe, it's at least that it's not a financial reason because often the farmers that farm organic or biodynamic are actually better off financially.

[753.5s - 762.4s]: It can't be an environment reason because because the environment is better off with these farming systems.

[763.2s - 765.2s]: So there must be a social reason for this.

[765.6s - 778.1s]: And I found that one of the main licking links is that many research projects or even educational projects don't show farmers.

[778.1s - 798.6s]: So you have this the scape that farmers don't, farmers are not shown in explaining their their thoughts and explaining how they implemented certain practices and why what their strategies are to overcome challenges or how they test different things.

[798.6s - 810.8s]: And that's quite interesting, I think that we developed into a system that where the voices of farmers are sometimes not very heard enough.

[812.6s - 828.3s]: And with the living farms project, we wanted to change that in a way, we wanted to show their solutions and we wanted to let farmers really speak and let them show us how they are, how they change the system and what their steps are.

[828.6s - 842.8s]: And yeah, that's basically the idea to motivate other farmers to join the movement or to improve their own systems in a way by just looking at farmers and their farms.

[843.7s - 849.5s]: And to see what great work they are doing on the farms.

[849.5s - 877.3s]: Yeah, it's so wonderful. And yeah, the social aspect of this deep question of change and how to best realize substantial rapid change at scale around the world is so interesting and is, I think, a significant part of the theory of change, if you will, that we work with at the WON-Earth community.

[1647.8s - 1672.7s]: So when I just mentioned with the curiosity, but also with the social aspect that often biodynamic farms are places where people come together, then you have like often a very deep love to to the soil and to the animal and that you really and plants as well.
